title: 112_s1936
content:
The "Implementation of Simpson-Bowles Spending Reductions Act of 2011" limits appropriations to the White House and Congress to 85 percent of the funds allocated in fiscal year 2011 for the years 2012 through 2016. No cost of living adjustment for Members of Congress during fiscal years 2013-2015. Pay freeze for federal employees extended until December 31, 2015. Reduction in federal workforce. The President, through the Office of Management and Budget, must ensure that the total number of Federal employees does not exceed 90% of the total number as of September 30, 2011, starting in fiscal year 2015. The Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Office of Personnel Management, continuously monitors agencies to determine if the total number of Federal employees exceeds the maximum allowable. If it does, written notice is provided to the President and Congress within 14 days. Compliance is required for each quarter. (d) Compliance.--If the total number of Federal employees exceeds the maximum allowable, no agency can appoint new employees until written notice is given to the President and Congress. The notice must be provided within 14 days after the quarter ends. 
(e) Waiver.--The President can waive this requirement in case of emergencies, such as a state of war. The President can waive the restriction on appointing new federal employees in case of emergencies like a state of war or extraordinary emergencies threatening life, health, public safety, property, or the environment. The Office of Management and Budget will ensure agencies appoint no more than 1 employee for every 3 retiring employees to achieve necessary workforce reductions. The President can waive restrictions on appointing new federal employees in emergencies. Agencies must appoint no more than 1 employee for every 3 retiring employees. The counting rule requires determining employee numbers on a full-time equivalent basis. Measures will be taken to limit the increase in service contracts procurement, except when financially advantageous. SEC. 6. REDUCTION IN GOVERNMENT TRAVEL COSTS. The total travel expenses for each agency for fiscal years 2012-2016 cannot exceed 80% of the amount appropriated for fiscal year 2011. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON GOVERNMENT PRINTING COSTS. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will work with Federal departments to reduce Government printing costs, establish guidelines on employee printing, and publish cost-benefit analysis results on their website within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The website will publish results of a cost-benefit analysis on implementing a digital signature system and employee printing identification systems. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will ensure that Federal employee printing costs do not exceed $860,000,000 annually. Guidelines will be issued for departments to list their name on publications distributed to the public. The curr_chunk provides details on the publication of documents, including the commission or office, total number of copies printed, cost of production, and the publishing firm's name. SEC. 8. REDUCTION IN FEDERAL VEHICLE COSTS. The amount for new vehicles for the Federal fleet shall not exceed 80% of the amount for fiscal year 2010. SEC. 9. SALE OF EXCESS FEDERAL PROPERTY. Subchapter VII added for expedited disposal of real property. The term 'Director' refers to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. A 'landholding agency' is defined as an agency under the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act. 'Real property' includes excess, surplus, underperforming, or unneeded federal properties. The Director must dispose of real property worth at least $100,000,000 through sale or auction, excluding properties to be closed or realigned under specific legislation. The Director must dispose of real property valued at $100,000,000 or more that is not in use by the Federal Government from 2011 to 2015. Landholding agencies must recommend properties for disposal, which the Director can select with agency head approval. Selected properties must be listed on a regularly updated website. The Director may transfer real property for disposal to the Department of Housing and Urban Development if suitable for assisting the homeless. Additionally, the list of selected properties for disposal must be updated routinely and allow public access to updates via email. "Subchapter VII - Expedited disposal of real property includes definitions and a disposal program. Prohibition on earmarks is outlined in Section 10." Section 312 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to prohibit earmarks, limited tax benefits, and limited tariff benefits in bills, resolutions, or amendments in the Senate and the House of Representatives. A point of order can be raised in the Senate under this provision. Additionally, voting on the adoption of a committee of conference report is also prohibited if it includes earmarks. The Senate prohibits earmarks, limited tax benefits, and limited tariff benefits in bills, resolutions, or amendments. A point of order can be raised in the Senate to strike such material from a conference report, leading to further amendment considerations. The Senate allows for points of order to be raised to strike earmarks, limited tax benefits, and limited tariff benefits from conference reports or amendments. Any motion to waive points of order requires a two-thirds majority vote. The term 'earmark' refers to a provision included at the request of a Senator or Member of the House of Representatives for specific spending authority, while 'limited tax benefit' refers to a revenue provision providing a Federal tax deduction. The term 'limited tax benefit' refers to a revenue provision providing a Federal tax deduction, credit, exclusion, or preference to a particular beneficiary or limited group of beneficiaries under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with eligibility criteria that are not uniform in application. The term 'limited tariff benefit' refers to a provision modifying the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States in a manner that benefits 10 or fewer entities. This subsection does not apply to any authorization of appropriations to a Federal entity not specifically targeted to a State or locality. The authorization is not specifically targeted to a State, locality, or congressional district.
